field_edited_text.value:
Tugs at Fells Point’s Broadway Pier







The two types of industries described
above - those that are direct outgrowths
of maritime activity and those that rely
on water for their shipments or their
production process - are usually designated
water-dependent. These industries actually
use their waterfront locations to ship and
receive goods essential to their operations.
While the number varies from year to year,
it is estimated that between 40,000 and
60,000 people are employed in activities
directly related to the Port of Baltimore.

Other firms are located on or near the
harbor because they benefit from the avail-
ability of water transportation although
they are not dependent on shipping or
receiving goods by water from their own
sites. Such industries are designated
“water-related” and include Procter and
Gamble, E. Renneberg Machinery Co., and
Baltimore Copper Paint Co.



Carr-Lowery - glass container manufacture and B.G.&E.s
Westport Generating Station - non-water dependent industry



Finally, there are industries which are
neither water-dependent nor water-related
but which are nevertheless located on or
near the harbor. They neither directly use
the water for transportation purposes them-
selves nor do they significantly benefit from
the availability of water transportation.
Their location on the harbor may have
historical roots. At one time they may have
relied on the port for their operation, but
economic or technological changes may
have altered their dependency. Their loca-
tion near the water may have been
determined by factors completely unrelated
to the port, for instance low land costs.
Examples of non-port-related industries
around the Baltimore harbor are Locke
Insulators, General Motors, and Lever
Brothers. It is estimated that over 20,000
people are employed by firms not directly
tied to the port’s operations.





22
